en-us.learning_promise:
In this unit, your students will construct, analyze, and/or interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships between types of energy (i.e., metabolic, potential, and kinetic) and an object's acceleration. 

Developing models to illustrate the amount of energy stored in a system, they'll practice finding mathematical relations, and play with statistics and probability to find answers to a scientific question. In doing so, your students must consider the limitations of data analysis (e.g., measurement error) and/or seek to improve the precision and accuracy of data using better technological tools and methods (e.g., multiple trials).

lessons.student_worksheet_description: You eat something every day. You absorb energy every day. And every day, you use that energy. But how does it work?

step.title: Take a moment to answer these questions.

text.content:
- [ ] Can you name two smart tracking devices and describe what they can track?
- [ ] Which type of energy are you spending when you exercise?
- [ ] How can you measure that energy?
- [ ] Which unit would you use to measure that energy?
- [ ] Done! I have played the program and I've seen the exercises.

lessons.student_worksheet_description:
Yoga isn't easy. It requires precision. 
Let's say you've decided to start doing yoga. How could you track the precision of your movements?

step.title: Take a moment to answer these questions.

text.content:
- [ ] What are some ways of determining whether or not a movement is precise?
- [ ] How could you graph values to represent real-life movement?

lessons.lesson_description: Graph energy consumption to gain potential energy.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Graph energy consumption to gain potential energy.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Have you ever tried to ride a bike uphill? What happened, or what do you think would happen? That's exactly what's coming in this lesson!

step.title: Take a moment to answer these questions.

text.content:
- [ ] What will happen to your speed when you go up a hill?
- [ ] What type of energy do you gain as you go up?
- [ ] What do you need to do to maintain a consistent energy level of you on your bike (your system)?
- [ ] Why do you think that's the case?

reduced_palette.title: SPIKE Prime Science This is Uphill

step.title: Lets build you, on a smart bike!

text.content: - [ ] Done! I've built my bike.

building_instruction.title: SPIKE Prime Science This is Uphill

text.content:
- [ ] My bike is moving forward and recording values.
- [ ] I can see my graph.
- [ ] I can answer these questions:
- Why isn't the angle read by the Hub "0?"
- Why is there a weird curve at the beginning of the power line?

text.content:
- [ ] I can see my new graph.
- [ ] I can answer these questions:
	- How can you describe what's happening to the motor's power as the bike goes uphill?
	- Looking at the graph, where can you see that your bike is gaining potential energy?

step.title: Repeat with a different slope. Make a prediction!

text.content:
- [ ] I've created my path.
- [ ] I've made my estimation graph.
- [ ] I was able to record my data and verify my graph.

- [ ] How would you summarize your experiment?
- [ ] Can you describe one way to gain potential energy?

Nice work in the field!

teacher_support.things_you_will_need:
- LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Prime Set
- Device with the LEGO Education SPIKE App installed
- A plank or something to create a slope

lessons.title: SPIKE Prime Science This Is Uphill

lessons.lesson_description: Graph potential energy at the maximum height of a jump.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Graph potential energy at the maximum height of a jump.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: The funny thing about jumping is that you'll always come back to the ground! Let's check out that transfer of energy.

step.title: Take a moment to answer these questions.

text.content:
- [ ] What's potential energy?
- [ ] How high can you jump?
- [ ] How can you measure the height of a jump?
- [ ] How much (potential) energy is that?

reduced_palette.title: SPIKE Prime Science Time for Squat Jumps

text.content: - [ ] Done! I've built my kettlebell.

- [ ] I know how to jump with the kettlebell.
- [ ] I can use the program and the graph to determine how high I've jumped.

- [ ] I can answer this question:

lessons.title: SPIKE Prime Science Time for Squat Jumps

lessons.lesson_description: Explore kinetic energy during a movement at constant speed.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Explore kinetic energy during a movement at constant speed.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: How much do you walk during the day? How fast do you usually walk? How much kinetic energy is that? Let's find out!

step.title: Take a moment to answer these questions.

text.content:
- [ ] How can you measure how fast you're walking?
- [ ] How can you measure or calculate the energy of an object in motion?
- [ ] Which type of energy is that?

reduced_palette.title: SPIKE Prime Science Watch your steps

text.content:
We will use it to measure your steps and how fast you can walk.

- [ ] Done, I have build my pedometer

building_instruction.title: SPIKE Prime Science Watch your steps

text.content:
- [ ] I've programmed my pedometer.
- [ ] I've walked 10 steps to try out my program.
- [ ] I've imported the data into my graph.
- [ ] I can answer this question:
	- How can you identify individual steps in your graph data?

comments.comment: This programming stack graphs your steps.
This programming stack tries to count your steps.

step.title: Adjust your program to detect your steps.

text.content:
- [ ] I've found threshold values by looking at my first experiment graph.
- [ ] I've adjusted and tested my program.

step.title: Convert your steps into a unit of speed, and then kinetic energy.

text.content:
- [ ] I've converted my steps into speed (distance/time). 
- [ ] I've walked slowly and then faster to see the change in speed.
- [ ] I've converted my steps into kinetic energy (½mv<sup>2</sup>).
- [ ] I've found a cool way to display energy levels!

- [ ] How would you summarize your experiment?

Looking good!

lessons.title: SPIKE Prime Science Watch Your Steps

lessons.lesson_description: Explore kinetic energy during a movement using variable speed.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Explore kinetic energy during a movement using variable speed.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Kinetic energy is reduced by friction. To hit a target, or to have friction stop the motion of an object at a precise location, you need to put the right amount of energy into the system first.

step.title: Take a moment to answer these questions.

text.content:
For an object slowing down, like a skateboard or a curling rock:
- [ ] What does the graph showing distance over time  look like ?
- [ ] What does the graph showing speed over time look like?
- [ ] What does the graph showing kinetic energy over time look like?

reduced_palette.title: SPIKE Prime Science Aim for it

text.content: - [ ] Done! I've built my street curling rock or freewheeling vehicle, or call it how you like!

building_instruction.title: SPIKE Prime Science Aim for it

text.content:
- [ ] I have a starting line and a target.
- [ ] I can push my curling rock toward the target and trace a graph.

text.content:
- [ ] I've changed my program to get my initial graph speed.
- [ ] I've tried a new push of my curling rock and I can log an approximate initial speed.
- [ ] My program is calculating and showing the kinetic energy at the beginning of my push.

- [ ] I've prepared the playing field.
- [ ] I've tried to hit the middle of the target 3 times.
- [ ] I've measured the distance between the target and where the rock stopped.

- [ ] I can answer these questions:
	- How would you summarize your experiment?
	- What have you learned?

Looking good!

lessons.student_worksheet_description: In any system, no energy is created, and no energy is lost. It's all about transferring energy from one place to the other!

step.title: Take a moment to answer these questions.

text.content:
- [ ] How are kinetic and potential energy related?
- [ ] Do you know of any obstacle course games?

step.title: Think about an obstacle course game you could build.

text.content:
- [ ] I've described 2 - 3 obstacle course games that I could build models of.
- [ ] I've described where the transfer of potential energy to kinetic energy can be observed in each game.

step.title: Choose, build, and name your model.

text.content:
- [ ] I've started building my chosen model.
- [ ] I've come up with a name for my model.

- [ ] I've programmed my model.
- [ ] I can log and display energy values.
- [ ] I can show that I've improved my results during testing.
- [ ] I've presented my model to my classmates.

- Are you pleased with your model's performance? 
 - Is there anything that you could’ve done better?

**Congratulations! You are now a Ninja of obstacle courses.**

en-us.title: SPIKE Prime Training Trackers
en-us.unit_plan_description: You're active, in a smart way. You always want to track how many steps you've walked and how much energy you've burned. But wait a minute! What is energy? Let's use a training tracker to find out!
en-us.unit_plan_subtitle: Graphing data to visualize various forms of energy.
